critical_instructions.item: Analyze ONLY the most recently sent image. Disregard all previous examples or images.
Absence of tables is a valid and expected outcome. Do not force identification if no tables are present.
When in doubt, do NOT classify an element as a table. Accuracy is more important than comprehensiveness.
NEVER classify paragraphs or text blocks as tables, even if they appear visually distinct or are formatted differently from the rest of the text.
Tables must contain data organized in a grid of rows and columns, not continuous text.

table_definition.item: A table is a structured arrangement of data in a clear grid format with multiple rows and columns.
Tables typically have a header row describing the content of each column.
Data in tables should have clear relationships and be organized systematically.
Tables primarily contain individual data points, not full sentences or paragraphs.
Each cell in a table typically contains a single piece of information, not a full paragraph.

not_tables.item: Paragraphs or blocks of text are NEVER tables, regardless of their formatting or visual distinction.
Abstracts, even if they appear in a box or with distinct formatting, are NOT tables.
Page layouts, even if structured, are NOT tables.
Headers, titles, author information are NOT tables, even if they contain aligned text.
Text blocks, regardless of their formatting or visual separation from other content, are NOT tables.
Any content that consists primarily of full sentences or paragraphs is NOT a table.

decision_process.item: Follow the two-step verification process defined in the table_verification_process.xml file.
In the first pass, identify all potential table-like structures.
In the second pass, rigorously verify each potential table against the defined criteria.
Consider the context around each potential table to avoid misclassification.
For verified tables, ensure you capture the full extent, including any continuations.
